a-foray-into-the-weeds-the-euler-fermat-.text: A foray into the weeds: the Euler-Fermat theorem

pageProps.body:
Random Applications

I have discovered a truly horrendous proof of the following theorem, which this margin is too large to contain.

A foray into the weeds: the Euler-Fermat theorem

(Weeds refers to number theory.)

Fermat is now considered a foundational mathematician in the development of calculus and number theory, but math was actually his side hustle; he worked as a lawyer for his day job, which makes him the benchmark every second-generation immigrant Asian kid would be compared to for the rest of history.

One of Fermat's most well-known results is Fermat's Little Theorem, which is also what Fermat's girlfriend called his pecker:

Theorem. Euler-Fermat Theorem (and Fermat's Little Theorem). Let n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N and a∈Za \in \mathbb{Z}a∈Z be coprime to nnn. Let ϕ(n)\phi(n)ϕ(n) be the Euler totient function, which computes the number of positive integers smaller than or equal to nnn that are coprime with nnn:

ϕ(n)=∣{m∈N: 1≤m≤n,gcd(m,n)=1}∣\phi(n) = |\{m \in \mathbb{N}:\ 1 \leq m \leq n, \text{gcd}(m,n) = 1\}|ϕ(n)=∣{m∈N: 1≤m≤n,gcd(m,n)=1}∣

Given the above, the Euler-Fermat Theorem states that for nnn, aaa and ϕ(n)\phi(n)ϕ(n), we have

aϕ(n)≡1 (mod n)a^{\phi(n)}\equiv 1\ (\text{mod }n)aϕ(n)≡1 (mod n)

Fermat's Little Theorem is a particular case of the above; for ppp prime, ϕ(p)=p−1\phi(p) = p-1ϕ(p)=p−1 (as every positive integer less than a prime is coprime to that prime), yielding

ap−1≡1 (mod p).a^{p-1}\equiv 1\ (\text{mod $p$}).ap−1≡1 (mod p).

(Side note: if nnn has prime factors p1p_1p1​, p2p_2p2​, ..., pkp_kpk​, ϕ(n)\phi(n)ϕ(n) admits the simple form

ϕ(n)=n(1−1p1)(1−1p2)...(1−1pk)\phi(n) = n(1-\frac{1}{p_1})(1-\frac{1}{p_2}) ... (1-\frac{1}{p_k})ϕ(n)=n(1−p1​1​)(1−p2​1​)...(1−pk​1​)

where 1−1p11-\frac{1}{p_1}1−p1​1​ calculates the number of positive integers less than nnn which are not multiples of p1p_1p1​, 1−1p21-\frac{1}{p_2}1−p2​1​ the number of positive integers less than nnn which are not multiples of p2p_2p2​, and so on; a positive integer is coprime with nnn if it shares no prime factors with nnn, resulting in the above representation.)

Proof.

The Euler-Fermat theorem has about a septillion bazillion different proofs, some of which are simple enough to be understood by five-year-old children playing with their ankle bracelets (as in, the proof actually involves an ankle bracelet, though thankfully it doesn't involve any five-year-old children). But did you know that through the power of group theory, we can prove the Euler-Fermat theorem in an extremely complex and needlessly convoluted way unappreciable by anyone who hasn't studied undergraduate math? Well, we can.

The basic idea is this: if GGG is a group, we know by a previous lemma that for all g∈Gg\in Gg∈G, we have

g∣G∣=eGg^{|G|} = e_Gg∣G∣=eG​

with ∣G∣|G|∣G∣ the order of the group; as a reminder, this is because ∣G∣|G|∣G∣ is a multiple of ord(g)\text{ord}(g)ord(g), which is just the order of the cyclic subgroup generated by ggg alone - and by Lagrange's theorem, the order of any subgroup divides the order of the group.

As such, if we can show that the positive integers less than nnn and coprime to nnn form a group UnU_nUn​ under some binary operation mod n\text{mod }nmod n - with identity 111 and ∣Un∣=ϕ(n)|U_n| = \phi(n)∣Un​∣=ϕ(n) by definition - we will have

gϕ(n)≡1 (mod n)g^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1\ (\text{mod}\ n)gϕ(n)≡1 (mod n)

where gϕ(n)g^{\phi(n)}gϕ(n) is understood be the binary operation, whatever it is, repeated ϕ(n)\phi(n)ϕ(n) times. For this to match the Euler-Fermat theorem, let's just say this binary operation is multiplication mod n\text{mod}\ nmod n:

a,b∈Un, a⋅Unb=ab (mod n)a, b\in U_n,\ a\cdot_{U_n} b = ab\ (\text{mod}\ n)a,b∈Un​, a⋅Un​​b=ab (mod n)

where ababab denotes multiplication in the "usual" sense. (I legitimately hate the fact that these words are part of my vocabulary now.)

So, is UnU_nUn​ a group under multiplication mod n\text{mod }nmod n on the set of all positive integers less than nnn coprime with nnn? For closure, let a,b<na, b < na,b<n be coprime with nnn; then

ab (mod n)=ab−kn=mab \ (\text{mod }n) = ab - kn = mab (mod n)=ab−kn=m

for some kkk by definition, which must also be coprime to nnn; if mmm was not coprime to nnn (i.e. m=cp1m = cp_1m=cp1​ for some prime factor of nnn, p1p_1p1​), we would have m+kn=ab=p1(...)m + kn = ab = p_1(...)m+kn=ab=p1​(...) which shares the prime factor p1p_1p1​ with nnn, and is thus not coprime to nnn. This is a contradiction, because ababab must be coprime with nnn by virtue of neither aaa and bbb sharing prime factors with nnn. Thus UnU_nUn​ is closed. Associativity is inherited from multiplication; the identity element is 111.

The inverse is a little bit trickier. For there to be an inverse, there would need to exist a unique a−1∈Una^{-1} \in U_na−1∈Un​ such that aa−1≡1 (mod n)aa^{-1} \equiv 1 \ (\text{mod }n)aa−1≡1 (mod n); this implies that

aa−1−kn=1aa^{-1} - kn = 1aa−1−kn=1

for some positive integer kkk. Such an a−1a^{-1}a−1 exists via Bezout's Identity, which I will neither acknowledge, explain, nor elaborate upon.

As such, UnU_nUn​ forms a group; and for any a<na < na<n already in UnU_nUn​, the Fermat-Euler Theorem is satisfied by the lemma we mentioned before -

a∣Un∣≡aϕ(n)≡1 (mod n).a^{|U_n|} \equiv a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1\ (\text{mod }n).a∣Un​∣≡aϕ(n)≡1 (mod n).

For a>na> na>n and aaa coprime with nnn, however, we know that aaa can be written as kn+rkn + rkn+r for some positive integers kkk and rrr, with a≡r (mod n)a \equiv r\ (\text{mod }n)a≡r (mod n) and rrr also coprime with nnn (r∈Unr \in U_nr∈Un​); if rrr wasn't coprime with nnn, aaa and nnn would share a prime factor. This leads to

aϕ(n)≡(kn+r)ϕ(n)≡rn+(powers of (kn)) (mod n)≡rn (mod n)≡1\begin{aligned} a^{\phi(n)}&\equiv (kn+r)^{\phi(n)} \\ &\equiv r^n + (\text{powers of $(kn$)})\ (\text{mod }n )\\ &\equiv r^n\ (\text{mod }n) \\ &\equiv 1 \end{aligned}aϕ(n)​≡(kn+r)ϕ(n)≡rn+(powers of (kn)) (mod n)≡rn (mod n)≡1​

by the Binomial Theorem. This yields the desired result. □\square□

Classifying small groups

Possibly the most important consequence of Lagrange's Theorem is that it dramatically narrows our search range for potential subgroups of a group; this is especially true for groups GGG of small size, whose small size guarantees a very limited number of divisors of ∣G∣|G|∣G∣ and thus a very limited number of subgroups.

Up until this point, we've studied a few families of groups that serve as candidates for subgroups: the cyclic group CnC_nCn​, the dihedral gorup D2nD_{2n}D2n​, and the permutation group SnS_nSn​. One last group needs to round out our happy family of three before we can fully classify every small group (with at most 8 elements).

Quaternions

A quaternion is what Gordon Ramsay tells me to simmer in my beef stock, probably.

Quaternions were first discovered by William Hamilton in 1843. As the legend goes, Hamilton was walking with his wife on a bridge at Cambridge when a flash of genius struck him, and he was moved to carve what have become the defining properties of quaternions on a rock on the bridge while his wife looked on in abject horror at a grown man suddenly dropping to the ground to play with rocks.

(Unfortunately, the rock has since been lost to time and the laws carved upon it weathered and gone. This makes Alexander Hamilton the second Hamilton in history to carve fundamental laws in stone only for them to have gone to shit.)

Definition. Later courses will reveal that quaternions are an extension of the concept of complex numbers to more complex units; however, this course won't. For the time being, the quaternions - of which there are four, hence the name - can be defined as the complex matrices given by

{1=[1001]i=[i00−i]j=[01−10]k=[0ii0].\begin{cases} \mathbf{1} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \\ \mathbf{i} = \begin{bmatrix} i & 0 \\ 0 & -i \end{bmatrix} \\ \mathbf{j} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \\ \mathbf{k} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & i \\ i & 0 \end{bmatrix}. \end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​1=[10​01​]i=[i0​0−i​]j=[0−1​10​]k=[0i​i0​].​

These four matrices can be verified to satisfy the properties (which William Hamilton carved in stone)

i2=j2=k2=ijk=−1.\mathbf{i}^2 = \mathbf{j}^2 = \mathbf{k}^2 = \mathbf{ijk} = -1.i2=j2=k2=ijk=−1.

(My textbook calls these properties "amusing", which is a statement made by someone who is probably a little wonky in the head.)

Proposition. Importantly, the set of quaternions along with their additive inverses {±1,±i,±j,±k}\{\pm \mathbf{1, \pm i, \pm j, \pm k}\}{±1,±i,±j,±k}form a group under matrix multiplication; call this group Q8Q_8Q8​, with 888 total elements. This arises from every one of the above quaternions satisfying x4=1x^4 = \mathbf{1}x4=1 and having periodic powers that exclusively equal the other quaternions.

With the quaternion group Q8Q_8Q8​, we're now equipped with everything we need to describe groups of small order - except for a few last preparatory statements.

Direct product theorems

Theorem. Chinese Remainder Theorem. Unfortunately, the Chinese Remainder Theorem is not a statement about the amount of leftovers I am expected to leave every time I eat Chinese takeout. If nnn, mmm have no common factors, then Znm\mathbb{Z}_{nm}Znm​ is isomorphic to the direct product Zn×Zm\mathbb{Z}_n \times \mathbb{Z_m}Zn​×Zm​ via the function ϕ:Znm→Zn×Zm, ϕ(a)=(a (mod n),a (mod m))\phi: \mathbb{Z}_{nm} \to \mathbb{Z}_n \times \mathbb{Z}_m,\ \phi(a) = (a\ (\text{mod}\ n), a\ (\text{mod}\ m))ϕ:Znm​→Zn​×Zm​, ϕ(a)=(a (mod n),a (mod m)).

(Unfortunately ϕ\phiϕ already denotes the Euler totient function, but I'm too illiterate in the Greek alphabet to think of anything different.)

Proof.

Firstly, this function is a homomorphism between the two groups (reminding ourselves that Zn\mathbb{Z}_{n}Zn​ is the integers modulo nnn, with addition as the binary operation):

ϕ(a+b)=((a+b) (mod n),(a+b) (mod m))=ϕ(a)+ϕ(b)\phi(a+b) = ((a+b)\ (\text{mod}\ n), (a+b)\ (\text{mod}\ m)) = \phi(a) + \phi(b)ϕ(a+b)=((a+b) (mod n),(a+b) (mod m))=ϕ(a)+ϕ(b)

The kernel of this homomorphism is all positive integers aaa that are both 000 mod mmm and mod nnn; as nnn and mmm have no common factors by assumption, no such integers <nm< nm<nm exist. As the kernel is trivial, if ϕ(a)=ϕ(b)\phi(a) = \phi(b)ϕ(a)=ϕ(b), then we have only ϕ(a)−ϕ(b)=ϕ(a−b)=0\phi(a) - \phi(b) = \phi(a-b) = 0ϕ(a)−ϕ(b)=ϕ(a−b)=0 implying that a=ba = ba=b. Therefore no two elements in Znm\mathbb{Z}_{nm}Znm​ map to the same element in Zn×Zm\mathbb{Z_n\times Z_m}Zn​×Zm​, and as both groups have nmnmnm elements, the image of the homomorphism is the entirety of Zn×Zm\mathbb{Z_n\times Z_m}Zn​×Zm​. Thus, the two groups are isomorphic; this implies that for integers aaa with

a≡k (mod nm)a \equiv k\ (\text{mod }nm)a≡k (mod nm)

for coprime nnn, mmm, there is a unique way to write

{a≡x (mod n)a≡y (mod m)\begin{cases} a \equiv x\ (\text{mod }n)\\ a \equiv y\ (\text{mod}\ m) \end{cases}{a≡x (mod n)a≡y (mod m)​

such that the two statements are equivalent.

Theorem. Direct Product Theorem. Let H1H_1H1​ and H2H_2H2​ be subgroups of GGG. GGG is isomorphic to their direct product H1×H2H_1 \times H_2H1​×H2​ if (but not only if):

  1. H1∩H2={e}H_1 \cap H_2 = \{e\}H1​∩H2​={e}
  2. If h1∈H1h_1 \in H_1h1​∈H1​ and h2∈H2h_2 \in H_2h2​∈H2​, then h1h2=h2h1h_1h_2 = h_2 h_1h1​h2​=h2​h1​, and
  3. For each g∈Gg \in Gg∈G there are h1∈H1h_1 \in H_1h1​∈H1​ and h2∈H2h_2 \in H_2h2​∈H2​ such that g=h1h2g = h_1 h_2g=h1​h2​.

Proof.

Consider the function ϕ(h1,h2)=h1⋅Gh2\phi(h_1, h_2) = h_1 \cdot_G h_2ϕ(h1​,h2​)=h1​⋅G​h2​ which maps from H1×H2H_1 \times H_2H1​×H2​ to GGG. This function is a homomorphism if

ϕ((h1,h2)⋅H1×H2(h1′,h2′))=ϕ(h1,h2)⋅Gϕ(h1′,h2′)ϕ(h1⋅Gh1′,h2⋅Gh2′)=h1⋅Gh2⋅Gh1′⋅Gh2′h1h1′h2h2′=h1h2h1′h2′h1′h2=h2h1′\begin{aligned} \phi((h_1, h_2)\cdot_{H_1\times H_2} (h_1', h_2')) &= \phi(h_1, h_2)\cdot_G \phi(h_1', h_2') \\ \phi(h_1 \cdot_G h_1', h_2 \cdot_G h_2') &= h_1\cdot_G h_2 \cdot_G h_1' \cdot_G h_2' \\ h_1h_1'h_2h_2' &= h_1h_2h_1'h_2' \\ h_1'h_2 &= h_2h_1' \end{aligned}ϕ((h1​,h2​)⋅H1​×H2​​(h1′​,h2′​))ϕ(h1​⋅G​h1′​,h2​⋅G​h2′​)h1​h1′​h2​h2′​h1′​h2​​=ϕ(h1​,h2​)⋅G​ϕ(h1′​,h2′​)=h1​⋅G​h2​⋅G​h1′​⋅G​h2′​=h1​h2​h1′​h2′​=h2​h1′​​

for all h1,h1′∈H1h_1, h_1' \in H_1h1​,h1′​∈H1​, h2,h2′∈H2h_2, h_2' \in H_2h2​,h2′​∈H2​; the above condition is satisfied by (2) - "If h1∈H1h_1 \in H_1h1​∈H1​ and h2∈H2h_2 \in H_2h2​∈H2​, then h1h2=h2h1h_1h_2 = h_2 h_1h1​h2​=h2​h1​". This function is isomorphic if its kernel is the identity and its image is the entire group GGG. Suppose that (h1,h2)(h_1,h_2)(h1​,h2​) lies in the kernel of ϕ\phiϕ:

ϕ(h1,h2)=h1⋅Gh2=e, h1=h2−1\phi(h_1,h_2) = h_1\cdot_G h_2 = e,\ h_1 = h_2^{-1}ϕ(h1​,h2​)=h1​⋅G​h2​=e, h1​=h2−1​

which would mean that h1h_1h1​ and h2h_2h2​ are in the same subgroup, as any element in a group must also have its associated inverse. However, by (1) ("H1∩H2={e}H_1 \cap H_2 = \{e\}H1​∩H2​={e}"), the only common element between the groups is the identity itself; thus, the kernel of ϕ\phiϕ is the identity.

Finally, the image of ϕ\phiϕ is guaranteed to be the entirety of GGG by property (3). Thus, ϕ\phiϕ is an isomorphism between H1×H2H_1 \times H_2H1​×H2​ and GGG.

Theorem. If every non-identity element in a finite group GGG has order 222, GGG is isomorphic to C2×C2×...×(C2C_2 \times C_2 \times ... \times (C_2C2​×C2​×...×(C2​ for a certain number of C2C_2C2​).

This multiple direct product is the group consisting of elements of the form

{(a1,a2,...,an) ∣ ai∈C2}\{(a_1, a_2, ..., a_n)\ |\ a_i \in C_2\}{(a1​,a2​,...,an​) ∣ ai​∈C2​}

with multiplication defined on a term-by-term basis, as before.

Proof.

Firstly, observe that the group GGG must be abelian: for any element g∈Gg \in Gg∈G of order 222 (which is every non-identity element, by our assumption), we have g2=eg^2 = eg2=e and thus g=g−1g = g^{-1}g=g−1, yielding

g1g2=g1−1g2−1=(g2g1)−1=g2g1g_1 g_2 = g_1^{-1} g_2^{-1} = (g_2 g_1)^{-1} = g_2 g_1g1​g2​=g1−1​g2−1​=(g2​g1​)−1=g2​g1​

as g2g1g_2 g_1g2​g1​ is also an element of order 2 by virtue of being in GGG.

Now consider what GGG looks like. Any element g1∈Gg_1 \in Gg1​∈G forms a subgroup with itself as the generator, G1={e,g1}≅C2G_1 = \{e, g_1\} \cong C_2G1​={e,g1​}≅C2​; if G=G1G = G_1G=G1​, then G≅C2G \cong C_2G≅C2​ and we are done. If instead there is an element g2≠g1∈Gg_2 \neq g_1 \in Gg2​=g1​∈G, then g2g_2g2​ also forms a subgroup G2={e,g2}≅C2G_2 = \{e, g_2\} \cong C_2G2​={e,g2​}≅C2​; so will g1g_1g1​ and g2g_2g2​ together, which generate the subgroup G1,2={e,g1,g2,g1g2}G_{1,2} = \{e, g_1, g_2, g_1g_2\}G1,2​={e,g1​,g2​,g1​g2​}. By the Direct Product Theorem, G1∩G2={e}G_1 \cap G_2 = \{e\}G1​∩G2​={e}, GGG is abelian, and some product of elements from G1G_1G1​ and G2G_2G2​ expresses all elements in G1,2G_{1,2}G1,2​; thus we have

G1,2≅G1×G2=C2×C2.G_{1,2} \cong G_1 \times G_2 = C_2 \times C_2.G1,2​≅G1​×G2​=C2​×C2​.

If G=G1,2G = G_{1,2}G=G1,2​ (i.e. ∣G∣=4|G| = 4∣G∣=4), then G≅C2×C2G \cong C_2 \times C_2G≅C2​×C2​. Otherwise, if there is one other element g3≠g1≠g2g_3 \neq g_1 \neq g_2g3​=g1​=g2​ in GGG, repeat the above process: G1,2,3G_{1,2,3}G1,2,3​, the group generated by g1,g2g_1, g_2g1​,g2​ and g3g_3g3​ (which is GGG itself), is isomorphic to the direct product C2×C2×C2C_2 \times C_2 \times C_2C2​×C2​×C2​, and so on. This can be done with any number of finite gng_ngn​. □\square□

Group classifications

Here we classify all groups of order 888 or less.

The identity/trivial group. {e}\{e\}{e} is the only group of order 111.

Prime-order groups. All groups of prime order ppp are cyclic. By Legrange's Theorem, such groups have no "actual" subgroups (besides the trivial subgroup and itself); as such there can be no element within it with order less than ppp, as that element would generate a subgroup. Thus all elements within the group have order ppp, which, by definition, corresponds to a cyclic group.

This rules out groups of order 222, 333, 555 and 777, which are all isomorphic to cyclic groups.

Order 4.

Proposition. All groups GGG of order 444 are isomorphic to either C4C_4C4​ or C2×C2=D4C_2 \times C_2=D_4C2​×C2​=D4​.

Proof.

By Lagrange's Theorem, an element g∈Gg \in Gg∈G has order 111, 222, or 444. If ggg has order 444, then by definition GGG is a cyclic group, as its elements are {e,g,g2,g3}\{e, g, g^2, g^3\}{e,g,g2,g3}; if ggg has order 111, ggg is the identity; and if ggg has order 222, we have

g=g−1.g = g^{-1}.g=g−1.

Suppose that GGG is not the cyclic group; it thus cannot have elements of order 444, only 111 (the identity exclusively) and three other elements of order 222. Let a,b∈Ga, b \in Ga,b∈G be two distinct non-identity elements of GGG with order 222. Then we have ab=(ab)−1=b−1a−1=baab = (ab)^{-1} = b^{-1} a^{-1} = baab=(ab)−1=b−1a−1=ba, and thus GGG is abelian; this is due to ab∈Gab \in Gab∈G and all elements of GGG having order 222, leading to (ab)−1=ab(ab)^{-1} = ab(ab)−1=ab. We also have a≠aba \neq aba=ab and b≠abb \neq abb=ab due to neither being the identity; thus, a,b,aba, b, aba,b,ab and eee form a complete group. The subgroups of this group arise entirely from

{a,e}, {b,e}\{a, e\},\ \{b, e\}{a,e}, {b,e}

which are both isomorphic to C2C_2C2​, and their direct product C2×C2C_2 \times C_2C2​×C2​ leads to {a,b,ab,e}\{a,b,ab,e\}{a,b,ab,e}. □\square□

Order 6.

Proposition. All groups GGG of order 666 are isomorphic to either S3S_3S3​ or C6C_6C6​. (The two groups are not themselves isomorphic because S3S_3S3​ has no element of order 666.)

Proof.

By Lagrange's Theorem, an element g∈Gg \in Gg∈G has order 111, 222, 333 or 666.

If ggg has order 666, then GGG is isomorphic to C6C_6C6​ by definition; this yields the result concerning C6C_6C6​. Otherwise, suppose that GGG contains only elements of order 222. By an above result, GGG is thus isomorphic to C2×C2×...×C2C_2 \times C_2 \times ... \times C_2C2​×C2​×...×C2​, and has order 2n2^n2n, not 666; thus, GGG cannot contain only elements of order 222 and must contain elements of order 333.

Now suppose that GGG contains only elements of order 333; these elements will form subgroups of the form Ga={e,a,a2}G_a = \{e, a, a^2\}Ga​={e,a,a2}. If b∈Gb \in Gb∈G is not in GaG_aGa​, then b2b^2b2 will also not be in GaG_aGa​, as (b2)2=b4=b(b^2)^2 = b^4 = b(b2)2=b4=b is not in GaG_aGa​. Thus GGG has at least the elements {e,a,b,a2,b2}\{e, a, b, a^2, b^2\}{e,a,b,a2,b2}; if there is a single other element ccc not equal to these five elements, ccc also has order 333 by assumption and c2c^2c2 will not equal any of the above (by the same argument as b2b^2b2). Therefore GGG is at least {e,a,b,c,a2,b2,c2}\{e, a, b, c , a^2, b^2, c^2\}{e,a,b,c,a2,b2,c2}, which contains 7 elements and not 6 - a contradiction.

Thus GGG must contain elements of both order 222 and 333. Let a∈Ga \in Ga∈G have order 222, and bbb have order 333, with a≠b≠ea \neq b \neq ea=b=e; then we have

G={e,a,b,b2}G = \{e, a, b, b^2\}G={e,a,b,b2}

at minimum. ababab does not equal any of these elements; if ab=eab = eab=e then b=a−1=ab = a^{-1} = ab=a−1=a as aaa has order 222, but b≠ab \neq ab=a; if ab=aab = aab=a then b=eb = eb=e, which is untrue; if ab=bab = bab=b then a=ea =ea=e, which is untrue; and if ab=b2ab = b^2ab=b2 then a=ba = ba=b directly, which is untrue. Similarly, ab2ab^2ab2 is also part of GGG and unequal to any of the above. Thus we have

G={e,a,b,b2,ab,ab2}G = \{e, a, b, b^2, ab, ab^2\}G={e,a,b,b2,ab,ab2}

which can be verified to be closed, and is of order 666. Finally, we notice that the above maps exactly to the dihedral group D6D_6D6​, with the rotation element r=br = br=b and the reflection element s=as = as=a; in turn, D6≅S3D_6 \cong S_3D6​≅S3​, leading to the desired result.

Order 8.

Proposition. All groups GGG of order 888 are isomorphic to one of the following: C8C_8C8​, C4×C2C_4 \times C_2C4​×C2​, C2×C2×C2C_2 \times C_2 \times C_2C2​×C2​×C2​, the quaternion group Q8Q_8Q8​, and the dihedral group D8D_8D8​.

The groups are not themselves isomorphic because C8C_8C8​ has an element of order 888, which no other group does; C2×C2×C2C_2 \times C_2 \times C_2C2​×C2​×C2​ has elements of order 222 only, which no other grouop does; and Q8,D8Q_8, D_8Q8​,D8​ and C4×C2C_4 \times C_2C4​×C2​ can be verified to not share elements with similar properties.

Proof.

The simplest case is the cyclic group: if GGG has an element of order 888, then GGG is isomorphic to C8C_8C8​ by definition. Otherwise, by Lagrange's Theorem, GGG has elements of order 111, 222 or 444 (not 888, as that would make GGG cyclic.) Ignoring elements of order 111, we have:

  1. GGG has only elements of order 222. By an above result, this leads to G≅C2×C2×C2G \cong C_2 \times C_2 \times C_2G≅C2​×C2​×C2​.

  2. GGG has an element of order 444: call this element fff. Then the subgroup generated by fff alone, denoted ⟨f⟩\langle f \rangle⟨f⟩, has the form

    {e,f,f2,f3}\{e, f, f^2, f^3\}{e,f,f2,f3}

    By the fact that left cosets partition ggg, we know that there must exist some g∈Gg \in Gg∈G and not in ⟨f⟩\langle f \rangle⟨f⟩ such that the coset g⟨f⟩={g,gf,gf2,gf3}g\langle f\rangle = \{g, gf, gf^2, gf^3\}g⟨f⟩={g,gf,gf2,gf3} are the remaining elements of GGG. The question is, what is the order of ggg? If g2∈g⟨f⟩g^2 \in g\langle f \rangleg2∈g⟨f⟩ we would have g=fng = f^ng=fn for some n=0,1,2,3n = 0, 1, 2, 3n=0,1,2,3, which is a contradiction because it would make g⟨f⟩=⟨f⟩g\langle f \rangle = \langle f \rangleg⟨f⟩=⟨f⟩.

    Thus, g2∈⟨f⟩g^2 \in \langle f \rangleg2∈⟨f⟩; if g2=fg^2 = fg2=f then g4=f2≠eg^4 = f^2 \neq eg4=f2=e, yielding ggg as an element of order greater than 444 (and thus of order 888) - a contradiction, as that would make GGG cyclic. Thus we have g2=eg^2 = eg2=e or g2=f2g^2 = f^2g2=f2.

    If g2=eg^2 = eg2=e and not f2f^2f2, consider the element fgfgfg; it cannot be part of the coset ⟨f⟩\langle f \rangle⟨f⟩ because then we would have g=fng = f^ng=fn once again. Thus fg∈{g,gf,gf2,gf3}fg \in \{g, gf, gf^2, gf^3\}fg∈{g,gf,gf2,gf3}, and g−1fg∈⟨f⟩={e,f,f2,f3}g^{-1}fg \in \langle f \rangle =\{e,f,f^2,f^3\}g−1fg∈⟨f⟩={e,f,f2,f3}; g−1fgg^{-1}fgg−1fg has order 444 as fff has order 444, so g−1fgg^{-1}fgg−1fg must be either fff or f3f^3f3. If it is fff, then fg=gffg = gffg=gf; the Direct Product Theorem then shows that G=⟨f⟩×⟨g⟩=C4×C2G = \langle f \rangle \times \langle g \rangle = C_4 \times C_2G=⟨f⟩×⟨g⟩=C4​×C2​. Otherwise if it is f3=f−1f^3 = f^{-1}f3=f−1, we have

    g−1fg=f−1g^{-1}fg = f^{-1}g−1fg=f−1

    which defines the dihedral group D8D_8D8​, as ggg is order 222.

    Finally, consider g2=f2g^2 = f^2g2=f2; once again fg∈g⟨f⟩fg \in g\langle f\ranglefg∈g⟨f⟩ and g−1fg=fg^{-1}fg = fg−1fg=f or f3f^3f3. If the former, we have again the direct product C2×C4C_2 \times C_4C2​×C4​; if the latter, ggg is order 444, yielding a bijection with the quaternion group.
